title: 113_hr4065
content: The Act may be cited as the "Smartphone Theft Prevention Act". Congress finds that mobile device theft costs consumers $30 billion annually, with 1 in 3 robberies involving a mobile device. Efforts have been made by carriers, manufacturers, law enforcement, and the FCC to address this issue, but more action is needed. Consumers deserve the most secure technology to protect their information, as technological protections continue to advance and benefit the economy. Consumers deserve the most secure technology to protect their information, as technological protections continue to advance and benefit the economy. The wireless industry should collaborate with law enforcement to educate consumers about available security tools and how to keep their data, devices, and themselves safe. Engineering and security needs change rapidly. The mobile device industry, law enforcement, and consumer advocates should proactively develop solutions to protect consumers, drive innovation, and deter theft as engineering and security needs change rapidly. SEC. 3. FUNCTION FOR STOLEN MOBILE DEVICES. Part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new section, "SEC. 343. FUNCTION FOR STOLEN MOBILE DEVICES." In this section, the term 'account holder' for a mobile device refers to the person holding the account for commercial mobile service or data service, including authorized individuals. The term 'commercial mobile data service' is defined as per the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012. The term 'mobile device' refers to a personal electronic device used for commercial mobile service or data service. Providers of such services must ensure the functionality of these devices. Providers of commercial mobile service or data service must ensure that mobile devices have a function allowing the account holder to remotely delete or render inaccessible all their information on the device. Providers of commercial mobile service or data service must ensure that mobile devices have a function allowing the account holder to remotely delete or render inaccessible all their information on the device, render the device inoperable on any network globally, and prevent reactivation or reprogramming without a passcode. Providers of commercial mobile service or data service must ensure that mobile devices have a function allowing the account holder to remotely delete all information, render the device inoperable globally, and prevent reactivation without a passcode. Providers of commercial mobile service or data service must ensure that mobile devices have a function allowing the account holder to remotely delete all information, render the device inoperable globally, and prevent reactivation without a passcode. Additionally, a person may not manufacture or import a mobile device in the US unless it is configured to reverse any unauthorized actions and comply with device standards. Providers of commercial mobile service or data service must ensure that mobile devices have a function allowing the account holder to remotely delete all information, render the device inoperable globally, and prevent reactivation without a passcode. The United States prohibits the manufacture or import of mobile devices unless they are configured to reverse unauthorized actions and comply with device standards. The FCC may exempt mobile service providers from certain requirements if they use functionally equivalent technology. The FCC may exempt mobile service providers and manufacturers/importers from certain requirements if they use technology that achieves the same functions required for mobile devices. The FCC may exempt manufacturers and importers from certain requirements if their mobile devices are configured to allow the provider to offer necessary technology. The FCC may waive requirements for low-cost, voice-only mobile devices if they are primarily intended for voice service. The FCC may waive requirements for low-cost mobile devices primarily intended for voice service and limited data consumption functions focused on text messaging. Providers cannot charge fees for certain functions on mobile devices. The FCC prohibits charging fees for specific functions on mobile devices and imposes forfeiture penalties for violations determined by the Commission. The FCC imposes forfeiture penalties on violations of subsections (b) or (c) of section 503, in addition to any other penalties provided for in the Act. Manufacturers and providers of mobile services are allowed to take actions not specified in the section to protect consumers from mobile device theft. The FCC allows manufacturers and providers of mobile services to take actions to protect consumers from mobile device theft, as specified in section 343 of the Communications Act of 1934. The Communications Act of 1934, specifically section 343, applies to mobile devices manufactured or imported into the United States after January 1, 2015. The FCC may grant compliance extensions for certain requirements under this section. The FCC may exempt a person from compliance requirements under section 343(b) of the Communications Act of 1934 for a temporary period if they need more time to comply.
